an8.74:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.
an8.74:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an8.74:4.3: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.
an8.74:5.1: And how is mindfulness of death developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial, to culminate in the deathless and end with the deathless?
an8.74:5.2: As day passes by and night draws close, a mendicant reflects:
an8.74:5.4: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
an8.74:5.5: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.
an8.74:5.7: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.
an8.74:5.8: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.
an8.74:5.11: ‘Are there any bad, unwholesome qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die tonight?’
an8.74:6.1: Suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:6.2: there are such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:7.1: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:7.2: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unwholesome qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an8.74:8.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:8.2: there are no such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, continuing to train day and night in wholesome qualities.
an8.74:9.1: Or else, as night passes by and day draws close, a mendicant reflects:
an8.74:9.3: A snake might bite me, or a scorpion or centipede might sting me.
an8.74:9.4: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.
an8.74:9.6: Or I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds. Or I might be attacked by humans or non-humans.
an8.74:9.7: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to me.
an8.74:9.10: ‘Are there any bad, unwholesome qualities that I haven’t given up, which might be an obstacle to me if I die today?’
an8.74:10.1: Suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:10.2: there are such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then in order to give them up they should apply outstanding enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:11.1: Suppose your clothes or head was on fire. In order to extinguish it, you’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness.
an8.74:11.2: In the same way, in order to give up those bad, unwholesome qualities, that mendicant should apply outstanding enthusiasm …
an8.74:12.1: But suppose that, upon review, a mendicant knows that
an8.74:12.2: there are no such bad, unwholesome qualities. Then that mendicant should meditate with rapture and joy, continuing to train day and night in wholesome qualities.
an8.74:12.3: Mindfulness of death, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in the deathless and ends with the deathless.”
